publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-384 Fergus Ewing: Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme—That the Parliament is concerned about the familial exclusion in the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme; believes the denial of civil compensatory redress for victims of incestuous sexual abuse before 1979 is a nonsensical and harmful exclusion; agrees with the views expressed by MPs Maria Fyfe and Menzies Campbell that the legal loophole should be closed by Westminster and wishes to express its support for victims of sexual assault in seeking justice in both the civil and criminal arenas. Supported by: Colin Campbell*
S1M-384 Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme (lodged on 15 December 1999) Tommy Sheridan*

S1M-384 Fergus Ewing: Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme—That the Parliament is concerned about the familial exclusion in the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme; believes the denial of civil compensatory redress for victims of incestuous sexual abuse before 1979 is a nonsensical and harmful exclusion; agrees with the views expressed by MPs Maria Fyfe and Menzies Campbell that the legal loophole should be closed by Westminster, and wishes to express its support for victims of sexual assault in seeking justice in both the civil and criminal arenas. Supported by: Colin Campbell, Tommy Sheridan, Fiona McLeod*
S1M-384 Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme (lodged on 15 December 1999) Andrew Wilson*, Alasdair Morgan*, Alex Neil*, Ms Margo MacDonald*
S1M-384 Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme (lodged on 15 December 1999) Christine Grahame*
S1M-384 Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme (lodged on 15 December 1999) Nick Johnston*, Brian Adam*

S1M-384 Fergus Ewing: Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme—That the Parliament is concerned about the familial exclusion in the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme; believes that the denial of civil compensatory redress for victims of incestuous sexual abuse before 1979 is a nonsensical and harmful exclusion; agrees with the views expressed by MPs Maria Fyfe and Menzies Campbell that the legal loophole should be closed by Westminster, and wishes to express its support for victims of sexual assault in seeking justice in both the civil and criminal arenas. Supported by: Colin Campbell, Tommy Sheridan, Fiona McLeod, Andrew Wilson, Alasdair Morgan, Alex Neil, Ms Margo MacDonald, Christine Grahame, Nick Johnston, Brian Adam
